subject: Law
title: Jim Crow Laws and Legal Segregation
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Jim Crow Laws and Legal Segregation.

hook.text: After slavery ended, Southern states created new laws to keep Black and white people apart. They called it 'Jim Crow.'

buildup.text: Jim Crow laws mandated segregation in schools, transport, restaurants, restrooms, and every public space imaginable.

discovery.text: Plessy v. Ferguson (1896) upheld segregation, ruling 'separate but equal' was constitutional. Facilities were never so.

twist.text: Segregation was enforced not just by law but by violence. Lynching and threats kept Black citizens from resisting.

climax.text: Brown v. Board (1954) overturned Plessy. The Civil Rights Act (1964) dismantled Jim Crow's legal framework.

punchline.text: Separate was never equal. The law finally admitted it.

quiz.question: What case upheld the 'separate but equal' doctrine?
